awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Assessing the Effects of Stress Physiology on Long-lasting Memory in a Free-living Animal
awd_abstract_narration:
Glucocorticoids, commonly known as "stress hormones", can affect the formation of short-term memories (i.e., memories that last from seconds to days), but the effects of stress hormones on memories that persist for months to years are unknown. Additionally, many memory studies use laboratory animals, which often have different behaviors and physiologies than their free-living counterparts. This research will assess the effects of stress hormones on the long-lasting memory of free-living Florida scrub-jays, a long lived bird that retains memories for years. A better understanding of how stress mediates memory may improve the post-release survival of captive-bred endangered species. Many conservation programs teach endangered animals the dangers of predators prior to release into natural habitats, and a strong memory of the identity of potential predators is essential for an animal's survival. This research may also have impacts on the study of human disorders that impair long-lasting memory, such as post-traumatic stress disorder and Alzheimer's disease. In addition, this research will provide research opportunities for University of Memphis undergraduates, over 40% of which are from groups underrepresented in science.

Stress can mediate memory function via glucocorticoids (GCs), which are released at low baseline concentrations, but increase in response to a stressor. For example, exposure to increased levels of circulating GCs shortly after learning typically enhances long-term memory formation. Long-term memories last hours to weeks, whereas memories that persist for months to years are known as long-lasting memories. Despite the robust knowledge of the effects of GCs on short- and long-term memory, the understanding of the effects of GCs on long-lasting memory is essentially nonexistent. The goal of this study is to understand how circulating glucocorticoids affect the long-lasting memory of an emotionally arousing event. The researchers will manipulate circulating levels of GCs in free-living Florida scrub-jays (Aphelocoma coerulescens) during a fear conditioning protocol wherein subjects will be either conditioned to avoid an artificial, novel predator or exposed to a non-threatening control. The researchers will then measure subjects' avoidance of the novel predator 48 hours and 10 months post-conditioning to assess the role of GCs in consolidation and retention of the associative memory. All data and analysis from this research will be made publically and freely available on GitHub, a free, web-based Git repository hosting service, at https://github.com/Jonesbc.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to understand the effects of stress physiology on the consolidation and long-lasting retention of learned antipredator behavior in a free-living animal. We manipulated circulating levels of corticosterone (the primary glucocorticoid in birds; CORT) in free-living Florida scrub-jays (FSJs; Aphelocoma coerulescens) during a fear-conditioning protocol wherein subjects were conditioned to avoid one of two distinctly different artificial novel predators. We measured subjects’ avoidance (i.e., flight initiation distance – FID, distance at which an individual flew upon approach of the novel predator) of the conditioned artificial predator and the unconditioned control 48 hours and 6 months post-conditioning to assess the consolidation and retention of the associative memory and whether glucocorticoid treatment affected the process. 

We tested how FID was influenced by exogenous CORT treatment (oral doses of 0, 10, and 20 mg, Fig. 1), time post-conditioning (48 hours and 6 months), and predator exposure type (threat-conditioned and novel control). We found a significant three-way interaction among our three predictor variables (F2, 128.37 = 6.95, P = 0.001). We examined interaction contrasts (i.e., differences of the differences) between control and conditioned responses across time for each group of CORT-treated individuals (Fig. 2). Individuals given no or a high dose of CORT responded more fearfully (i.e., greater FIDs) to the novel predator controls despite never being conditioned to avoid them. In contrast, the difference between control and conditioned responses increased with time for individuals given a low dose of CORT (10mg; Fig. 2). Generalization may explain why some individuals respond to novel predator controls just as fearfully as predators they had been conditioned to avoid. Generalization occurs when a conditioned response (e.g., FID) is elicited by a stimulus that is different than the original conditioning stimulus (e.g., control novel predator), and may explain the significant interaction contrasts across CORT treatments.

The project has allowed co-PI Jones to build upon and expand the scope of his previous dissertation research. The project also provided Stephen Ferguson, a lab-mate in the Schoech lab, the opportunity to participate in an area of study unrelated to his own research program. Additionally, Marissa Langager, a field assistant who recently earned her BS degree, was trained by BCJ in the multitude of field biology techniques including field identification of individuals, handling, and blood sample collection. Similarly, Ethan Schaffer, a former high school student at Memphis University School, was trained by and assisted BCJ to run enzyme linked immunoassays for glucocorticoid quantification.

Our understanding of the effects of stress physiology on learning and memory is lacking in at least two areas. First, little empirical evidence has been published on the links between stress physiology may affect learning and memory in free-living animals. Second, there has been little empirical evidence of how stress physiology may affect long-lasting memory (memory that lasts from months to a lifetime). Our project addresses these gaps in our knowledge by evaluating the effects of stress on long-lasting memories in free-living Florida scrub-jays. Additionally, the results show that the degree to which individuals generalize their conditioned response is influenced by CORT exposure during memory consolidation, which, to the best of our knowledge, is a novel finding. The integrative, cross discipline nature of the project will be of interest to researchers working in the areas of general ornithology, cognition, learning and memory, stress physiology, and behavioral endocrinology.

We developed a unique protocol modelled after the fear-conditioning paradigm used to study learning and memory in laboratory rodents. Our study demonstrates that this is a feasible method to assess the effects of stress physiology on learning and memory in free-living birds (and likely other taxa). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first experimental protocol developed to investigate how free-living animals learn and retain information about potential predators. We hope that adaptation of our methods makes future study of learning and memory in free-living animals more feasible to behavioral ecologists and field endocrinologists.

Conservation programs have improved the survival of reintroduced endangered species by fear conditioning naïve, captive reared animals to avoid natural predators. Our findings demonstrate the link between stress physiology and memory formation of a novel predator in a threatened species. Conservation programs may improve species recover by designing predator avoidance conditioning protocols that elicit the optimal memory enhancing stress response, and selecting physiological phenotypes that best learn and retain anti-predator information.

Results and materials from this project have been incorporated into presentations and lectures for high school and homeschool classrooms. Specifically, BCJ has used the results and novel predators of this project to lecture about behavioral endocrinology as a guest instructor at White Stations High School in Memphis, TN and the East Tennessee Homeschool Group in Knoxville, TN.
